The prepared reaction mixture was poured into a stainless-steel autoclave,which was rotated in an oven after being sealed, and heated at  80 1C for 4 h before additional heating at 166 °C for different times (denoted as ‘‘80 1C, 4 h; 166 1C, x h’’).
The solid was fil-tered, washed with water, dried and finally calcined in air flow at 823 K for 20 h.
The gel was heated with tumbling at 423 K for 7-10 days.
Certain amounts of amorphous SiO2 and GeO2 were mixed with Me3PrN+OH- solution, and the mixture was stirred until a uniform suspension was formed.
The mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 175 °C for 14 days.
The colourless single crystals were filtered, washed with ethanol, and then dried at 60 °C overnight.
The sample was calcined at 200 °C in O3 for 6 hours to remove the organic species in the channels.
The colourless single crystals were filtered and washed with ethanol, and then dried at 60 °C overnight.
The mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 175 °C for 14 days.
The gel was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and crystallized at 200 °C for 72 h after stirring for 2 h.
The mixture was heated to 90 °C and maintained at this temperature for 4 h under vigorous stirring.
The precipitate was filtered and washed until it was free from chloride ions.
About 0.04 g seeds were added to the suspension and the liner was then sealed inside the 23-mL autoclave, and heated at 160 °C under tumbling conditions (about 40 rpm).

For preparing the seed slurry, 1.92 g KOH was dissolved in 10 g distilled water in a plastic bottle under stirring condition, then 0.20 g Al foil was added to the bottle that was capped loosely to let H2 gas evolved out.

After the Al foil was completely dissolved in the solution, another solution composed of 5.7 g tetraethylammonium hydroxide, 15.7 g ludox, and 8 g distilled water was added dropwise under drastic stir.
After that, the stir was continued for extra 60 min.

The gel thus obtained was then transferred to a poly-(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel autoclave with a capacity of 100 ml, which was subsequently heated at 150 °C for a certain period of time under rotation(20 rpm).
The mixture of NH4-SAPO-18 and 0.01 M copper acetic solution (solid to liquid ratio: 1/100) was stirred vigorously at 80 °C for 1 h.
The slurry was filtered and washed with deionized water in order to avoid the formation of copper oxide species.
Then the solid was dried and calcined at 550 °C for 4 h.
Subsequently, 0.05 g hexamethylenetetramine was added to the solution and then stirred at 70 °C.
Then the slurry was filtered, washed, dried, and then calcined at 550 °C for 4 h.
Then, the liquid was transformed to an autoclave, heating at 180 °C or 90 °C.

For large scale zeolite synthesis (using 3.0 g fumed silica as silicon source), the crystallizations were performed in a reflux glass flask with or without stir, in which the TPAOH/SiO2 ratio was twice of that in little scale zeolite synthesis.

As the concentration (21 wt%) was slightly lower than that (25 wt%) of the initial TPAOH solution, little amount of concentrated TPAOH solution (50 wt%) was added in dropwise until the concentration back to 25 wt%.
After being stirred at room temperature for 12 h, the synthesis mixture was charged into Teflon-lined autoclaves and heated at 100 °C, with rotating (60 rpm), for 14 d.
In addition, the acid-treatment seeds (HC-Seed, see below), 10 wt% of the silica in the synthesis mixture were added to the above mixture.
The rest synthesis procedures were same to the TP-UZM-9, except that the synthetic time was 2 d, and the product obtained by adding the acid-treated samples as seeds was denoted as seed-UZM-9.
Mixing 1.3 g TP-UZM-9 and 0.4 M HCl at room temperature under stirred for 2 h,then the rest solids were centrifuged, washed with distilled water until a value of pH 7 was reached.
Then, the resulting mixture was vigorously stirred at 80 °C for 4 h.
The solid was centrifuged and thoroughly rinsed with deionized water.

Subsequently, the Cu ion exchange was prepared by mixture 2 g NH4+-UZM-9 with 100 ml copper nitrate (99% Cu(NO3)2, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd) solution with different Cu(NO3)2 con centrations.
Then, the slurry was vigorously mixed at 80 °C for 4 h and then filtered and washed with deionized water for several times.
After that, the washed sample was dried at 100 °C for overnight and the above procedures were repeated for several times to obtain various Cu/Al ratios.
2 g Cu-4.10 and Cu-5.40 were mixture with 60 ml 0.05 M Mn(NO3)2 solution.
After that, the washed sample was dried at 100 °C for overnight and the above procedures were repeated for several times to obtain various Cu/Mn ratios.
The preparation process of Mn-y catalysts were as follows: 2 g NH4+-UZM-9 were mixture with 60 ml 0.5 M Mn(NO3)2 solution and 0.05 M Mn(NO3)2 solution, respectively.
Then, the slurry was vigorously mixed at 85 °C for 5 h, then filtered and washed with deionized water for several times.
After that, the washed sample was dried at 100 °C for overnight.
The obtained samples were further calcined at 500 °C for 4 h.
Prior to the activity test, each sample was pretreated in 5% O2/N2 at 600 °C for 2 h.
The mixture was stirred until the ethanol formed during hydrolysis and the excess of water were evaporated and the desired gel composition was reached.
Then, an aqueous solution of HF (48 wt%, Aldrich;0.47 g)was added and the mixture was introduced into a Teflonlined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 135 °C under staticconditions.
The solid was thoroughly washed and filtered with distilled water and acetone, then dried at 100 °C overnight.
The particles were calcined at 580 °C for 5 h, with an intermediate step at 350 °C for 3 h.
The polymer was dried at 100 °C before use.
The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h before casting on glass flat plates (although some membrane batches were prepared in steel flat plates with no significant improvement).

Although zeolites were usually added in high loadings to rigid polymer matrices, in this work loadings as low as 4, 8 and 12 wt% ITQ-29 were introduced into the polysulfone matrix for the generation of MMMs.

In a typical synthesis, H2O, N,N,N-trimethyl-1-ammonium adamantane (25 wt% TMAdaOH, 75 wt% H2O) and H3BO3 (99.8 wt%) and aluminum isopropoxide (AlP) (24.7 wt% Al2O3) were successively added into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave.
The mixture was stirred vigorously to form clear and transparent solution, then the fumed silica gel was added.

The TMAdaOH solution, H2O, sodium aluminate (44.15 wt% Al2O3, 36.08 wt% Na2O), sodium hydroxide (96 wt%) and fumed silica gel were successively added into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and then stirring vigorously the solution to form a homogeneous gel.
After crystallized at 423 K for 4 days, the obtained sample was firstly calcined at 873 K for 6 h, then 1 g powder sample was added into 50 g of 1 M NH4Cl solution at 353 K and stirred for 2 h.
Firstly, 1 g BAl-CHA-138 sample was mixed with 30 mL of 2 M HCl-EtOH solution in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave.
Then it was transferred to an oven with 443 K to react for 12 h.
After calcined at 823 K for 5 h, the obtained sample is named as BAl-CHA-138-DB.
In brief, solution A was made by 23.5 g (NH4)2CO3 dissolved in 150 g H2O and solution B was prepared by 37.5 g Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O and 29.75 g Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O dissolved in 150 g H2O.
The solution A and B were added dropwise into a breaker at the same time under vigorous stirring at 343 K while keeping the pH value of their mixture around 7.
After ageing for 3 h at 343 K, the solid product was filtrated, dried at 373 K for 12 h and further calcined at 773 K for 4 h.

The synthesis gel was prepared by adding tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 97%, Merck) and GeO2 (99.998%, Aldrich) to an aqueous solution of the MPP(OH)2 under continuous stirring and using aluminium isopropoxide (98%, Aldrich) as the Al source.
The gel was then autoclaved in Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves at 448 K for 12 days.
The final solid was recovered by filtration, exhaustively washed with water and dried at 373 K overnight.
The resulting ITQ-22 solid was calcined at 853 K in air in order to obtain the acid zeolite.
The procedure can be briefly described as follows: 0.5 g of EU-1seeds was pretreated while stirring in a solution of 12.0 g HMBr,2.0 g NaOH, and 150.0 g water at 50 °C for 2 h.

Subsequently,152.5 g of an aqueous solution of sodium aluminate (0.5 g of sodium aluminate, 2.0 g of NaOH) was added to the seed solution under vigorous stirring; the mixture was aged for 12 h at 50 °C.
The final mixture was stirred further at room temperature for 4 h and then heated in a Teflon-coated stainless steel autoclave at 160 °C for 40 h.
After filtration, the obtained solid was washed thoroughly with deionized water and then dried at 120 °C overnight.
Syntheses were carried out at 160, 180, and 200 °C, varying the crystallization time to study crystallization kinetics.
Typically, 20 ml of the polycationic agent solution was taken in 80 ml of water and added to 8 g of 13X powder.

Typically, 20 g of 1 M TPAOH was added drop-wise into 17.8 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS,99%, Sigma-Aldrich) solution under vigorous stirring for 3 h at room temperature till the solution was clear.
When the silicalite gel turned turbid, pre-treated zeolite 13Xpowder was added to it and the mixture was stirred for about 30 min.
The PPE bottle was then kept in an oven 24 h at 353 K.
Finally the 13X and silicalite gel mixture was centrifuged, washed repeatedly with deionized water and dried at 363 K overnight.

Then, 520 ml of water, 450 ml of ethanol and 4.5 ml of ammonia solution (28 wt.%) were rapidly added into the dispersion with continuous stirring for 0.5 h, followed by drop-wise addition of 1 g of TEOS in the solution under vigorous stirring for 6 h.
The precipitate was separated by centrifugation.

2.36 g of KOH and 0.25 g of aluminum powder (99 wt.%; impurities: iron 0.29 wt.%, silicon 0.27 wt.%, and copper 0.26 wt.%;) were successively added into 19.1 g of deionized water under stirring to get the homogeneous solution A.
Solution B was prepared by adding successively 14.3 g of colloidal silica and 4.96 g of tetraethylammonium hydroxide into 10 g of deionized water under stirring.
Then, solution B was added into solution A to make the gel mixture.
Afterward, 0.05 g(0.1 wt.%) of the SUZ-4 seed was added to the above gel, followed with a further aging at room temperature for 24 h.
The synthesis gel was finally transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and left in the oven statically at 160 °C for 3 days under the autogenous pressure.
Once homogenous gel formed, the remaining solution containing PEG and/or CTAB was added in droplets under stirring.
Then the gel was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave hydrothermal crystallized at 443 K for 6-14 days.
Finally, the products were calcined at 823 K for 6 h in air to remove the organic compounds occluded in the zeolite.
The boron-containing SFN-type zeolites (B-SFN) was synthesized as reported at hydrothermal conditions in a rotating Teflon-lined autoclave (40 revolutions per minute) at 433 K for 8 days.
The obtained crystalline solid was washed with distilled water and dried at 373 K, then calcined in air at 823 K for 6 h.
The calcined B-SFN zeolite was deboronated by treatment with 6.0 M HNO3 solution (50 mL/g-zeolite) at 373 K for 24 h.
The deboronated product (DeB-SFN) was placed in a quartz tube reactor, and then pretreated at 773 K for 4 h in a dry nitrogen stream (30 mL/min).
Subsequently, the temperature of the reactor was raised to 873 K.
The nitrogen stream was diverted through an anhydrous TiCl4 solution maintained at 303 K.
The TiCl4 vapor saturated in nitrogen flow was carried into the reactor to contact the zeolite for 30 min.
After the treatment, the sample was purged with pure nitrogen at the same temperature for 1 h to remove any residual TiCl4 from the zeolite powder.
After cooling to room temperature in a nitrogen stream, the treated sample was calcined at 873 K for 4 h to obtain Ti-SFN zeolite.
In a typical run, the reaction was carried out with 25 mg Ti-SFN catalyst, 1.0 mmol cycloalkene and 1.0 mmol H2O2 in 2.0 mL acetonitrile.

The amine 1-benzyl-pyrrolidine (bp) was synthesized by adding 80.6 g of benzyl chloride (Sigma–Aldrich, 99 wt%) to a solution of 68 g of pyrrolidine (Sigma–Aldrich, 99 wt%) in 150 ml ethanol, in the presence of K2CO3.
40.0 g of bp were added to a solution of 53.2 g of CH3I (50% exc.,Fluka) in ethanol.
The reaction was carried out at room temperature for five days with stirring.

Finally, the required amount of HF (48 wt%,Panreac) was added drop wise and the resulting thick gel was hand mixed, loaded into 20 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves and heated statically at the crystallization temperature for selected periods of time.

A 1 L stainless steel hydrogenation reactor (equipped with a pressure gauge and heating mantle) was charged with 200 g (1.4 mol) 2-methylquinoline(Aldrich), 300 ml glacial acetic acid, 10 g platinum oxide catalyst, and 15 ml concentrated sulfuric acid.
The organic fraction was then washed with water and brine and subsequently dried with anhydrous magnesium sulfate.
In the next step N-ethyl-2-methyldecahydroquinolinine is prepared by adding 111 g iodoethane (0.72 mol) to a solution of 100 g 2-methyldecahydroquinoline (0.65 mol) in 350 ml acetonitrile.
The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 96 h.
Thirty grams iodoethane (0.19 mol) were then added to the suspension, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 72 h.

In a typical synthesis, 6.0 g of 0.50 M aqueous solution of trans-fused N,N-diethyl-2-methyldecahydroquinolinium hydroxide, 1.2 g of 1 N aqueous sodium hydroxide, an additional 4.8 g of de-ionized water, and 0.065 g of sodium borate decahydrate were mixed in a 23 ml Teflon liner.
The mixture was hand-stirred until the sodium borate was completely dissolved.
Then, 0.9 g of CABO-SIL-M5 (98% SiO2, 2 % H2O) was added to the mixture.
Typically, a certain amount of Ludox AS-40 (40 wt% silica sol in H2O, purchased from Aldrich) was added into the solution of NaOH under stirring.

And then the fresh solution of NaAlO2 (41 wt% Al2O3) was added slowly; after that, the solution containing SDA (Et6-diquat-n, n = 5, 6) was dropped in a slow manner, leading to a sol–gel composition in molar ratio of 30–100 SiO2:Al2O3:(2.1–19.5 Na2O):5.9 SDA:2454 H2O.
The final mixture was charged into a Teflon-lined 50-mL autoclave, and was heated to the required temperature under rotations (45 rpm).
After the crystallization for several days, the product was recovered by filtrations, washed with water, and dried overnight.
Briefly, 0.35 mL of TEOS was added into the slurry of 1 g of COK-5 in 5 mL cyclohexane under vigorous stirring.
After 12 h, the slurry was dried and calcined at 773 K for 4 h.
The impregnated extrudates were subsequently calcined in air at 773 K for 2 h.

A 25 wt% aqueous solution of hexamethonium hydroxide (N,N,N0,N0,N0-Hexamethylhexamethylenediammonium dihydroxide) was prepared by stirring a mixture of hexamethonium bromide (Acros) and silver oxide (Alfa Aesar) in water.
Precipitated silver bromide was removed from the final solution by filtration.
Finally, impregnated extrudates were placed on a porous holder located in the middle of a stainless steel autoclave (100 cm3).
For those prepared in the presence of an external water source, 5 cm3 of water were poured at the bottom of the autoclave.
Afterwards products were recovered, washed with distilled water and dried at 373 K.
For the use in a catalytic experiment, as-synthesized samples were first calcined for 18 h at 823 K in air to remove the organic template.
Samples were then calcined for 6 h at 823 K in air.
m-xylene (density: 0.86 g mL-1) was fed with a flow rate of 0.6 mL h-1 together with N2, with a m-xylene/N2 molar ratio of 0.02.
To fill up the fixed-bed, catalysts were mixed with carborundum particles with an average size of 2.4 mm.
When the catalyst was introduced into the reactor, air was passed through while increasing the temperature up to 623 K,and keeping this temperature for half an hour.
Then, air was changed to N2.
When stabilized, m-xylene was fed and the reaction was carried out at 623 K during 4.5 h.
In a typical procedure, an alumosilicate solutions was prepared by dissolving catapal B (AlOOH, 77% Al2O3) in choline hydroxide (45% ACROS or 46% Alfa Aesar or 50% ABCR) under vigorous stirring.

The reaction mixture which had a molar composition of 0.8–1.2 OH-:SiO2:0.1–0.2 Al2O3 was continuously stirred for 1 h to form a homogeneous gel before loading it into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL).
The starting mixture was put in an oven at 100 °C overnight.
After heating, a clear, homogeneous alumosilicate solution was obtained as product.

Solution B was then prepared by dissolving Sr(NO3)2 or LiCl or both together at substoichiometric levels with respect to Al in an appropriate amount of distilled water and added slowly dropwise to solution A under vigorous stirring.
The final reaction mixture was transferred into a 50 ml Teflon-lined autoclave and crystallized in an oven at fixed temperatures between 100 and 130 °C for 6–20 days under static conditions.
After washing with ammonium nitrate solution for 10 min the sample was calcined again at 350 °C for 2 h.
Prior to sorption measurements, calcined samples were kept in vacuo (i.e., degas) at 473 K for 4 h.

Typically, the synthesis gel was prepared as follows: 38.8 g fumed silica (SiO2, 99.8%, Shenyang Chemical Co.) was added to 110.0 mL of R(OH)2 solution (1.7 mol/L) in a 250 mL glass beaker under continuous stirring at room temperature.
When TEOS was used as silica source, 108.8 g TEOS (98%, Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Co.) was mixed with 90.0 mL of R(OH)2 solution (1.7 mol/L) in a 250 mL glass beaker.
And the mixture was continuously stirred with prolonged time (at least 5 h) to make sure the hydrolysis of TEOS and evaporation of the formed ethanol proceeded almost completely.
Previous to the crystallinity determination and N2 adsorption measurements, the samples were calcinated at 853 K in the air for 3 h to remove the occluded organics.

A mixture of 3,3,5-trimethylcyclohexanone (5.0 g; 35.5 mmol) and pyrrolidine (5.0 g; 71.0 mmol) was heated in ethanol (50 ml) over 10% palladium on charcoal at 160 °C for 4–96 h under H2 pressure (5 MPa).
Diaion SA10A anion-exchange resin was added to a solution of a cis- and trans-[ETMCHP]+I- (7.00 g, 19.8 mmol) in water (200 mL), and the mixture was stirred gently at room temperature for 3 days.

A solution of NaOH (32 wt.%, NaOH 384 mg),[ETMCHP]+OH- (cis/trans ratio = 53/47) (0.700 mmol/g; 14.3 g),and sodium borate decahydrate (Na2B4O7·10H2O; 362 mg) was stirred until the solution became clear, and 3.00 g (50 mmol) of fumed silica and 26.1 g of de-ionized water were added to the homogeneous mixture.
The mixture was transferred to a 23-mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave stored in a convection oven at 160 °C for 5 days, and the material was stirred at 66 rpm.
To remove organic SDA in the zeolite,the as-synthesized [B]-SSZ-60 was calcined in a muffle furnace under a flow of air (100 mL/min).
Finally, the calcined [B]-SSZ-60 zeolite was cooled to room temperature under ambient conditions.
The higher degrees of crystallinity were obtained by the addition of [B]-SSZ-60 seed (2 wt.% versus SiO2) to the gel to enhance the formation of the zeolite.
[B]-SSZ-60 was aluminated to form [Al]-SSZ-60 by heating in a solution of Al(NO3)3 at 80 °C for 18 h.
[Al]-SSZ-60 was obtained by calcination at 550 °C for 6 h.
Subsequently, the alkene was supplied to the autoclave, and the temperature and pressure were maintained throughout the reaction.
After cooling the autoclave, the products were separated from the catalysts by filtration.
The resultant solid product was collected by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried in air at 353 K overnight, giving rise to the layered precursor of PLS-3 silicate.
The solid product was collected by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried overnight at 353 K.
Typically, 1.0 g of ECNU-9(P) was added to a mixture of 0.23 g of TMCS silane and 50 mL of 1.0 M HCl/Ethanol solution.
And then, the resulting mixture was kept at 443 K in static for 20 h.

Typically, ECNU-9 after calcination at 773 K (ECNU-9-cal773), H2TiF6 (60 wt% aqueous solution) and H2O were charged into a Teflon beaker at a weight ratio of 1 : 0.21 : 25, and the mixture was further stirred at 308 K for 5 h.
Then the solid product was separated from the solution by filtration, washed with a plenty of distilled water.
The synthetic gel was charged into a stainless autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner and heated at 443 K for 24 h under static conditions, resulting in Ti-PLS-3 layered precursor.
The mixture was stirred vigorously at 333 K for 2 h.
1.0 g of PLS-3 was added to a mixture of 0.21 g of 1,3,5,7-tetramethylcyclotetrasiloxane (TMCS) and 50 mL of 1.0 M HCl/Ethanol solution.
The resulting mixture was then kept at 443 K in static for 20 h.
After silylation, the solid was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, and then dried at 353 K.
The ZSM-5 precursor suspension with the following chemical composition: 1 SiO2: 0.357 TPAOH: 0.004 Al2O3: 16.189 H2O,  was prepared under stirring and then aged for 18 h on an orbital shaker.
Separation and purifications of the harvested solids were performed by high speed centrifugation (20,000 rpm) and double-distilled water until the pH of the supernatant was 8.
The sample was dried at 80 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 5 h.

The single-site Mo-zeolite catalyst ([Mo]-ZSM-5) was prepared as follows: in a 125 mL polypropylene bottle, 3.0 g of the Mo-free calcined ZSM-5 nanosized zeolite, vide supra, was mixed with a solution containing 1.5 g of sodium molybdate (Na2MoO4, 4H2O, 98%, Alfa Aesar) solubilized in 50 mL of water under stirring.
The as-prepared mixture was then heated at 90 °C for 5 days under autogenous pressure.
The [Mo]-ZSM-5 crystals were purified by high speed centrifugation (20,000 rpm) until complete removal of unreacted Mo species from the supernatant.
The crystals were then dried at 80 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 5 h in air flow.
The obtained mixture was then dried at 120 °C for 3 hours and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h in air flow.

The procedure to obtain the pristine treated Mo-free zeolite was as follows: water was added to the pristine ZSM-5 crystals (6.65 g H2O for 300 mg ZSM-5), the obtained suspension was treated at 90 °C for 5 days, before being washed with water, dried at 90 °C overnight, and calcined at 550 °C for 5 h.
The obtained mixture was stirred further at room temperature for 30 min, and then transferred into an ice bath.
Meanwhile, hydrobromic acid solution (10.97 g, 48 wt.%, WAKO) was diluted to 20 wt.% with water and also cooled in the ice bath.

After the toluene solution was cooled for 1 h, another 4.76 g of isobutylamine (TCI) was added dropwise into the above mixture, which was followed by the addition of the cold hydrobromic acid solution (20 wt.%, WAKO).
Subsequently, glyoxal solution (9.44 g, 40 wt.%, WAKO) was added.
Purification was performed by adding 100 mL of water and 15 mL of saturated KHCO3 solution and further extracting with diethyl ether (100 mL, WAKO) twice.
The extracted aqueous solution was combined, treated with 1.20 g of activated carbon (Sigma-Aldrich) at room temperature overnight.
Further drying under vacuum yielded a salt of 1,3-bis(isobutyl) imidazolium bromide.

In the typical synthesis of 1,3-bis(cyclohexyl)imidazolium (C6-IM) hydroxide, cyclohexylamine (12.89 g, 98 %, WAKO) and 120 mL of toluene was mixed in a round-flask at room temperature, and then paraformaldehyde (4.10 g, 95%, WAKO) was added under stirring.
After the mixed solution was cooled for 1 h, another 12.89 g of cyclohexylamine (WAKO) was added slowly, which was followed by the addition of 30 wt.% cold tetrafluoroboric acid solution.
The flask was heated to 40 °C in a water bath and kept for 12 h.
The solid precipitate was filtered, washed with 100 mL of diethyl ether and dried overnight under high vacuum.

The typical procedure for the synthesis of 1,3-bis(cycloheptyl)imidazolium (C7-IM) hydroxide was similar to the synthesis of C4-IM expect for the use of the same molar amount of cycloheptylamine rather than isobutylamine, resulting in a solid organic product of 1,3-bis(cycloheptyl) imidazolium bromide after drying under vacuum.
The mixture was then transferred to a 25 mL stainless steel Teflon-lined autoclave (Parr, #4749) and heated at 150 °C for 5 days.
In the typical synthesis, the calcined silicate ITQ-1 was mixed with an aqueous solution of OSDA and then stirred at room temperature for 1 h.

The desirable amount of sodium aluminate (WAKO) and NaOH solution (5 wt.%) was introduced into the above solution, resulting in a synthetic gel with the molar composition of 1.0 SiO2 : 0.425 OSDA : 0.075 NaOH : 1/x Al2O3 : 40 H2O (x = silica-to-alumina ratio (SAR) = SiO2/Al2O3 = 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90, 100, 120, 150, 200, 400, 800).

The OSDAs in the as-synthesized samples were removed by calcination at 550 °C for 6 h to give the calcined form zeolite products, which were denoted as MWW-C4/C6/C7-SARx (x was the SAR of product that determined by ICP-AES analysis).
In a 500-mL, round-bottom flask, 25.00 g (148.2 mmol) 2-(chloromethyl)-1,3,5-trymethylbenzene and 14.08 g (171.5 mmol) 1-methylimidazole were solved into 300 mL THF.
33.22 g (141.8 mmol) OSDA1-Cl was solved into 250 mL deionized water.
42.346 g OSDA1-OH (8.003 mmol, [OH-] = 0.189 mmol/g) and 0.73291 g (7.004 mmol) GeO2 were added in a flask and stirred until a clear solution was obtained.
Then, 670 mL (3.001 mmol) TEOS (tetraethylorthosilicate) was added into the flask.

The solution was stirred allowing ethanol and water to evaporate until the targeted amount of water was reached, then 303 mL (8.014 mmol, c = 26.45 mol/L) HF was added into the solution under stirring.
After the solution changed into gel, the stirrer was removed and the gel transferred into a 30-mL autoclave.
With a tumbling speed of 60 rpm, the gel was crystallized at 160 oC for 4 d.
After finishing the crystallization, the sample in the autoclave was filtrated and washed with water (2 x 30 mL) and acetone (1 x 30 mL), and dried in an oven at 80 oC (0.655 g, Yield: 14.3%).
The synthesis solution with the molar composition of 1TEOS:0.3TPAOH:45H2O was prepared by introducing 13 g TEOS into aqueous solution containing 15.228 g TPAOH and 38.363 g H2O.
After being aged at 80 ºC under stirring for 24 h, the mixture was poured into a Teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave and crystallized at 170 ºC for 72 h.
Afterward, resulting solid products were centrifuged, washed with distilled water and dried at 70 ºC in an oven overnight.
0.2 g calcined parent MFI nanoseeds were added in 11.37 g 0.04 M TPAOH solution [1MFI (SiO2-based):0.14TPAOH:188H2O].
After sonication for 20 min, the mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave.
Afterward, obtained solid precipitates were recovered by centrifugation, washed with copious of DI water, and finally dried overnight at 70 ºC.

Hollow MFI seed layer or parent MFI seed layer was obtained by spin-coating the seed suspension containing hollow MFI nanoseeds (0.5 wt.% in DI water) or parent MFI nanoseeds (0.8 wt.% in DI water) at 3,000 rpm for 60 sec, respectively.
Finally, calcination was conducted at 550 ºC for 6 h with a heating/cooling rate of 1 ºC min-1, respectively.
The hollow MFI seed layer-modified substrate was then placed vertically in an 80 mL glass vessel and the clear sol solution was poured into the vessel.
Then the vessel was sealed and heated in a single-mode microwave oven (Discover, CEM) at 105 ºC for 2 h.
After synthesis, prepared H-MFI  membrane was rinsed in a 0.1 M ammonia solution for 12 h,  washed thoroughly with copious DI water, and finally air-dried in an oven at 70 ºC overnight.
Then, 0.1 g calcined hollow MFI nanoseeds were added in the above sol solution.

After sonication for 20 min, the mixture was transferred into a 80 mL glass vessel, and the vessel was sealed and heated in a single-mode microwave oven (Discover, CEM) at 105 ºC for 2 h under constant stirring (400 rpm).
Reduction of the imide 1: 14.31 g (85.14 mmol) of imide 1 were added under N2 atmosphere over a suspension of 8.10 g (212.86 mmol) in LiAlH4 in 300 ml of anhydrous tetrahydrofuran cooled at 0 °C.

Alkylation of the diamine 2: 33 ml (385.12 mmol) of methyl iodide were added over a solution of 7.25 g (51.74 mmol) of diamine 2 in 70 ml of acetonitrile.

In a typical synthesis of B-SFE, OSDA (DMAP) was first dissolved in deionized water in a 50 mL Teflon liner.
Then, boric acid was added, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min.
After that, ludox was added dropwise, resulting in a reaction mixture with molar composition of 1 SiO2:0.05 B2O3: xDMAP : y H2O, where x = 0.05–0.6, y= 5–25.
Before crystalli-zation, the starting mixture was sealed in a stainless-steel autoclave and aged for 1 hour under stirring at room temperature.
Crystalli-zation was carried out in a rotation oven at 170 °C for different times.
The organic species occluded in the framework were removed by calcination at 600 °C for 5 h in air atmosphere.
In a typical run, a mixture of 3.0 g Al,B-SFE, 2.0 g Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, and 50 mL H2O was sealed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclaves and heated at 120 °C for 3 days under static condition.
The obtained solids were washed twice with HCl solution (0.01 m) at room temperature to remove any solubilized Al salt, dried at 110 °C for 12 hours and calcined at 550°C for 5 hours in air.
The sample was recovered by centrifugation, washed with deionized water and dried at 110 °C for 12 hours and calcined at 550 °C for 5 hours in air.
In a typical procedure, lithium hydroxide monohydrate was dissolved in distilled water and fumed silica was then added to the solution.
After stirring for 2 h, a semitransparent suspension is obtained.
